subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] And now for something completely different.

messageBody:
Sid Tanaban scripsit:

> Stay
> with Shaw's if you want an accurate pronunciation of how an English
> speaker speaks English.  Or, if you want to write the correct accent
> to someone who who can write Shaw's the way he/she speaks.  Quikskript
> is not purely accurate in pronunciation.  

Well, everyone is entitled to their own opinion, but not their own facts.
First of all, the only distinction that Shavian makes that Quikscript
does not is between NURSE and LettER words, which are already fully
separated because the NURSE vowel always bears the stress and the LettER
vowel never does. So it is inaccurate to say that Shavian, if applied
consistently, is more accurate than Quikscript applied consistently.

Next, both alphabets fail to represent the English of all England.
Rather, they represent the accent of a handful (perhaps 3-5% in Read's
time, fewer today) of English people. Even then, both alphabets make
distinctions, like those between PALM and START, that do not exist in
RP either now or then (and very grateful the rest of us may be for
them, indeed). The accents of the huge mass of English people, and
almost everyone outside England (about 89% of all anglophones) are not
so well represented. Both alphabets make distinctions irrelevant to
99.6% of anglophones, which can be borne, but fail to make essential
distinctions such as that between the vowels of "fork" and "pork", or
the sounds of "poor" and "pure", which is much worse. (And if you say,
"We can live without those", I point out that about 62% of all anglophones
manage fine without distinguishing all three sounds written Ah, Awe, On.)
